body: Working on adding more to this.

This seemed to break the NodeJS tests (`lib/nodejs/test/testAll.sh`). Note these do not currently run on CI, which is why this likely slipped through the net. Note that it seems the test failures are catching a real issue with this change, so can this be reverted?
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/THRIFT-5537 is still open

Not sure what's gone on here in terms of linking commits to PRs, but presumably this was merged as commit 8b6d29d3ee7fb1bece7be1eb728e2e88e867cc2b.

I will repeat what I've said on the commit for visibility:

This change makes the thrift compiler segfault during execution of the NodeJS tests. Note these tests are not run on CI, which is why this will have slipped through the cracks.

I'm going to submit a PR to run the NodeJS tests on CI, but these are currently broken due to this PR and #3014. What's the best thing to do here? Should these changes be reverted?

I've tested it locally, running all the commands that the CI does, and I think that should resolve all the issues.

I can submit another PR, but it may take a few days before I can put that up.

> Should these changes be reverted?

No but we accept pull requests., Would that work for you? 
Alternatively, a minimal viable example how to reproduce could help too.
Where are the github actions status checks? Do they not run on PRs that come from different repositories?

> > Should these changes be reverted?
> 
> No but we accept pull requests., Would that work for you? Alternatively, a minimal viable example how to reproduce could help too.

This was actually an issue with incremental compilation. Ignore the above.
@Jens-G can I get another approval on the CI run? Hopefully it'll be fixed now ðŸ¤ž

For legal/licensing reference:

The Apache License Version 2.0 clause 5 implies that by submitting the Contribution (in the original PR), the code from the original author is under the terms of the Apache License Version 2.0.
I've opened https://github.com/apache/thrift/pull/3085 to succeed this PR.
@dependabot rebase
@dependabot rebase
cc @jimexist, since it seems you have been working on the conversion to GitHub actions primarily.

> Thanks for this, we were actually planning to add something similar but for the browser. We can make a follow up PR to add support for esm on the browser side as well.

That's interesting, because this is our exact use case, but we use the nodejs package in the browser. Is your plan here to support es modules that can directly execute in the browser, with no build tools at all?

> While testing this locally we noticed import statements are not changed to the esm format.

I must have missed this, I'll push an update. It also will need syncing with the nodejs CI changes (#3082).

> While testing this locally we noticed import statements are not changed to the esm format.

How do you exercise this code path? All of the tests files inside `gen-nodejs-esm` use `import` rather than `require`. Is this episodic generation that triggers this?

> We tried to use this PR's changes to build our own service, and when looking inside the generated files, we noticed that the import statements are like this:

Does this happen when a thrift file includes another thrift file? I don't think this is something the tests are covering atm. I'll investigate and add a test for it.

> We had some issues when integrating the nodejs thrift build into our project, so we thought it would be nice if we could decouple the esm build from the nodejs dependencies. And of course, supporting native esm browser packages would be beneficial too :D
However, it is good to know that the nodejs version worked for you - I will take another look and check if we are missing anything in our project's build tool!

It worked for us by polyfilling a few NodeJS dependencies (such as `util`, `Buffer`, etc), but I've been wanting to remove the dependencies on these since in modern JS environments there are cross-runtime alternatives. See [THRIFT-5844](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/THRIFT-5844). In fact we have a few PRs in the works that should remove these.

Another part that is missing is browser tests for the NodeJS package, but I also have plans to contribute these too.

This does call into question the necessity of a separate nodejs and js package. Does anyone do web development without a bundler currently?
Could you rebase and push again pls?
Currently some of the language tests are failing so we don't really run cross tests in CI so this cannot be verified in CI.

@tri613 @thomasbruggink I've updated this to render includes correctly, plus added a test (`include.test.mjs`) for this.

However, CI will fail on this until #3087 is merged, since the current version of eslint and prettier do not support the dynamic import syntax, and the nodejs tests now rely on this.
cc @jimexist, since it seems you have been working on the conversion to GitHub actions primarily.

> This does call into question the necessity of a separate nodejs and js package. Does anyone do web development without a bundler currently?

At the moment we rely on the web version while also having a bundler in place. It looks to me like the web version is a leaner but less feature rich (although using some older standards like xmlhttprequest).
I haven't checked this into detail but I wonder if there is a benefit to keeping the more lightweight web version around :thinking:
Superseded by #3092.

Related ticket in thrift:
 - https://github.com/apache/thrift/pull/3076 (a few weeks ago)
Looks like com.diffplug.spotless is up-to-date now, so this is no longer needed.
@Jens-G  could you please merge this PR? v0.20 fails to compile when _GLIBCXX_DEBUG is defined and this patch fixes the failure. The code appears to be correct.

I've looked through the code for as much as I can, without stepping with a debugger. As far as I can tell, it looks correct and clean now. I agree that the old code seems rather limited, for example in that it `asserts` that the given argument is the end iterator. The new code does look more clean and more versatile.

All with a grain of salt, because I did not step through the code. But if it furthermore was tested by @africamonkey , I'd vote for merging.
